description: From Middle English ritten (“to cut, score, slit, tear”), from Old English *rittan (“to cut, score, slit, tear,”) (compare Old High German rizzen), from Proto-West Germanic *rittjan, from Proto-Germanic *ritjaną (“to cut, scratch”), from Proto-Indo-European *wrid-néh₂-; see *hrītaną.
Cognate with Middle Low German ritten (“to scratch”), German ritzen (“to scratch”). Compare with Proto-Slavic *rězati (“to cut, carve, engrave”)). See also rat.

entries.meaning: (Northern England, Scotland) A scratch, a score or a groove.

verbs.description: rit (third-person singular simple present rits, present participle ritting, simple past and past participle ritted)

entries.meaning: (Northern England, Scotland) To scratch or score.
(Northern England, Scotland) To tear, rip, rend.
